**Earth Dragon Classic Explained**
**First Section**
The *Earth Dragon True Classic* excels in *ground-attacking strength*. Regardless of the opponent’s height, reach, or power, all can be overcome with *ground-attacking strength*. For humans, the upper body is often solid, while the lower body is often weak. Even in ordinary sparring, attacking below is more effective than attacking above—how much more so against those with great internal power! However, to practice this method, one must first master the *Internal Power Classic*, *Trigram Absorption Classic*, and *Spiritual Movement Classic*, training them to proficiency before applying the *Earth Dragon Classic*. Otherwise, the forms will be empty, and the secrets contained within the classics will remain unknown.

Though the *Earth Dragon Classic* forms a complete system, its principles interweave with the *qi* channels and connections of the *Internal Power*, *Trigram Absorption*, and *Spiritual Movement Classics*, mutually reinforcing each other. Scholars must not overlook this. The *Earth Dragon* system is entirely encompassed by the two words: *ground attack*. Though it contains boundless discussions, principles, methods, and transformations, all emerge from these two words.

**Second Section**
*Train the entire body on the ground to strengthen essence and clarity*. When facing an opponent, do not merely train the soles of the feet—lying fully on the ground further trains *qi*, blood, sinews, and spirit, enabling the use of whole-body power in all directions. Only then can one control and release. Training *qi* solidifies, training sinews strengthens, and training spirit sharpens. This work lies in daily practice, as described in the classics—do not resort to heterodox methods.

**Third Section**
*Extension can become contraction; stillness can become movement. Contraction resembles a crouching tiger; extension compares to a soaring dragon. Movement and stillness leave no trace; contraction and extension conceal their tracks.*

This means that when the opponent approaches, I immediately lower my body to the ground. Press both hands forward on the ground while the soles of the feet remain planted, then lift the entire body to hover above the earth. From there, respond to the opponent’s position and apply techniques freely—this is the standard method. If using contraction, gather whole-body power and drag backward with both hands to rise from a crouch. If extending, thrust forward with both feet to strike the opponent. There is no fixed pattern for movement or stillness; adapt to the opponent’s actions. When they are still, I move—all to prevent the opponent from discerning my traces.

Occasionally, contract the body so that neither hands nor feet are visible, concealing oneself with full power. Rest the head upon the hands to observe the opponent’s strength and weakness, assuming the posture of a crouching tiger. Hands and feet remain capable of striking the enemy as if rising to stand normally. When leaping, extend the entire body straight—whether turning or rolling, one can still subdue the opponent. Rising and twisting freely, one crouches like a soaring dragon.

Thus, to crouch one must first leap, and to leap one must first crouch. Crouching is the momentum of leaping, and leaping is the mechanism of crouching. One leap and one crouch, one extension and one contraction—transformation appears.

**Fourth Technique**
The body is firm as iron, the method dense as a dragon, overturning like fierce tigers and leopards, turning swift as falcons and eagles. This technique emphasizes the four characters: firmness, density, swiftness, and ferocity. Yet without comprehending the entire system of the Four Classics, one cannot grasp its subtlety. Only after thoroughly understanding the Four Classics and then applying them can one act freely.

For if not dense, one loses; if not firm, one falters. Once the body touches the ground, the enemy is drawn into one’s trap and cannot escape. Moreover, one must overturn with the ferocity of tigers and leopards, and coil with the swiftness of falcons and eagles—only then will there be no gaps. Otherwise, even if the enemy is caught in the technique, one cannot achieve the desired effect.

Turning and rolling, crouching and rising, constitute the *overturning force*; left and right rotations constitute the *shifting force*. When rotating, both feet extend straight; when overturning, slightly bend one foot—only then can vertical and horizontal forces remain distinct and unconfused.

**Fifth Technique**
Distinguish clearly between front and back, left and right. When the enemy approaches head-on, throw the entire body backward to land behind them, leaving them no time to react. This is called *forward collapse*; otherwise, falling backward onto the ground would place one at a disadvantage, with the enemy controlling from afar while one controls from close range. The subsequent method is called *backward collapse*. As for front, back, left, and right, these rely on the skill of leaping and dodging.

If the enemy attacks directly, shift the entire body outward—left or right—to make their strike miss, then immediately drop to the ground. Seize the moment to apply techniques; by the time the enemy adjusts their stance, they will have already fallen into one’s method. A single collapse secures victory—one need not meticulously distinguish front, back, left, or right to reach this realm of transformation.

**Sixth Technique**
The stance has variations, the method has no fixed form. The *stance* refers to the posture one adopts: crouching can shift to rising, rising to crouching; side can become reverse, reverse can become side—these are the rules for establishing stances according to the moment, not to be rigidly adhered to.

As for the method, there is no set pattern: sometimes the method follows the stance, sometimes the stance follows the method, and at times the method departs from the stance or the stance from the method—all depends on daily mastery of the Four Classics. Only with profound understanding can one respond naturally in the moment. Without it, even with verbal instruction, one cannot grasp the essence, let alone through mere observation.

Turning, rolling, crouching, and rising are the *stances*; hand and foot attacks are the *methods*. When the stance is near, the method changes; when the method is near, the stance changes. Endless coiling gives rise to layers of subtle techniques.

**Seventh Technique**
Frontal attacks employ the palm; the second and third stances share this principle. A *frontal attack* means when the enemy is before you, respond by attacking with your front. Use the palm—regardless of left or right—first seal their heel with one hand, then with the upper hand forcefully bend their knee outward from the inside. Alternatively, use both hands to seal their feet. The upper three stances fiercely attack the *Zusanli* point.

If the enemy’s foot is near your chest, swiftly bend your three stances from top to bottom to strike their instep—this too can secure victory. The second stance method is most effective when executed swiftly. If the enemy presses too close, guard against their foot attack, which is why the *dispersing stance* should not be used lightly.

**Eighth Technique**
Rear attacks employ the foot; both heel and knee are applicable. When the enemy is below you, respond by attacking with your lower body. Use the foot—regardless of left or right—first entangle one of their feet, then advance the other foot to forcefully strike their knee. Whether turning, rolling, crouching, or rising, left or right, up or down, one can bend, extend, rotate, and maneuver freely. Success requires exhausting all subtleties without the slightest obstruction to be considered proper.

When using the heel: if the enemy’s step is slightly distant and your foot can reach but not entangle, there is no need for entanglement. Simply lift one foot into the air and strike their instep from above. If they retract, immediately launch the other foot to strike again. If the enemy’s step is near your crotch, there is no need to switch to the previous method—simply use a kneeling strike to their instep to secure victory.

The above six methods are also mentioned in the *Neigong Dispersing Stance*, but all derive from this entanglement—there is no separate doctrine. The *heel* refers to the high bone at the back of the foot. Though described as striking from above, it is actually a diagonal strike, not a direct one. *Kneeling* refers to both knees. When using them, do not lift too high—excessive height renders the strike weak and powerless.

**Ninth Technique**
When distant, pursue and strike; when near, intercept. If the enemy suddenly retreats, do not allow them to withdraw freely—pursue them. However, pursuit does not require changing to a high stance; press both hands to the ground, lift the crotch, and extend both feet forward from beneath it—greater distance is preferable.

If the feet have already closed in the previous stance, bend the entire body and propel forward with both hands—this too can close the distance, with greater distance being ideal. When pursuing and applying techniques, freely alternate among the six methods above. If, just as you set the technique, the enemy suddenly advances, do not dodge left, right, front, or back.

**Following the Momentum to Apply Technique**
Seize the opportunity to engage with method—do not wait for the enemy to steady their stance and settle into position before advancing swiftly, for this is the way to ensure no technique misses its mark. The method of pursuit shares the same principle as *Divine Qi Circulation*, relying entirely on the two characters "suspended crotch." If the whole body lacks great strength, and the hands do not press firmly into the earth, the crotch cannot be suspended—how then could the feet leap and pursue at a distance? Only after internal skill and *Divine Qi Circulation* are thoroughly refined can this technique reveal its wonders.

**Tenth Technique**
*The Greater Hip Rests on the Ground, the Body Forms a Sideways Stance*
The "greater hip" refers to the outer hip bone. "The greater hip rests on the ground" means establishing a sideways stance on one’s side. Whenever employing this sideways falling stance, the tip of the single hip bone must touch the ground, both hands lightly pressing into the earth, while feet and knees lift entirely—thus enabling sinuous bending, stretching, and rolling movements, all derived from the sideways stance. In this technique, the hands must press lightly into the ground; if they bear weight, they become cumbersome. Press and lift in alternation, and the whole body will remain agile. One may also use only the two "gates" (hands) to touch the ground, allowing the feet to execute techniques freely as the situation demands.

**Eleventh Technique**
*Reclining as if Seated, the Tailbone Alone Bears the Weight*
When a person reclines on the ground, none do not sit with their entire buttocks. Yet to sit with the buttocks is to collapse the stance. To execute techniques, only the tip of the tailbone should touch the ground, while hands, feet, and body all lift—uniting the entire posture. Turn left to move left, turn right to move right, and apply techniques at will, all striking the vital points. One may also use only the hands to press into the ground, suspending the lower body to execute techniques and control the opponent. However, this is not as fluid or wondrous as the fully lifted posture, where above, both hands may be employed, and below, both feet—far more versatile and marvelous. Mastering this technique allows left and right spiraling, always centered on the vital pivot. Its subtlety defies description. Yet one must understand its principle: the tailbone serves as the pivot. If the buttocks press fully into the ground, the technique is lost entirely.

**Twelfth Technique**
*Height and Depth at Will, Distance and Range Unrestrained*
Some believe this method is limited to ground-level maneuvers, unable to rise for high attacks. Yet who knows that falling and rising at will, leaping and crouching freely, are the very essence of this classic? Any forced movement deviates from the proper form. To execute rising techniques, subtly bend one foot beneath you, gathering the body’s full power from the ground, assisted by both hands or a single hand. Regardless of left or right, reversal or forward lean, the body will naturally rise and fall at will. As for "unrestrained range," employ the high stance to leap outward, use the *Earth Dragon Classic* stance to retract, and deploy the *Earth Dragon* stance to extend—high to strike the enemy above, low to strike below. The key is to conceal all traces, ensuring movements are firm, swift, and fierce. This technique entirely follows the principles of *Divine Qi Circulation*. One who has thoroughly studied *Divine Qi Circulation* will grasp its unrestrained, soaring momentum, comprehend the principles of refining qi and spirit, and naturally achieve seamless mastery.

*The Orthodox Stances of the Scattered Gates*

**First Stance: Opponent Advances with Right Step and Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right step and lifting force (*liao jin*), I use my right hand to intercept their arm, guiding it from above downward and flinging it outward in one motion. Their flank will naturally expose itself. I then swiftly advance with my left *di lian* to seal their right step, employing the full techniques of the Second and Third Gates to attack from the side.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method requires adhering closely to the opponent’s back, using a compact body technique to lift upward—only then is it effective. As the opponent attacks, seize the moment they lower their stance, swiftly execute the right *ju bu* and the full *di lian* force to drive outward, raising the right hand to strike their back with a sweeping force (*lüe jin*). The three forces must be applied simultaneously to prevail.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This is a method for countering upward. When employing it, the legs must be fully extended, channeling the body’s *qi* in a backward diagonal pull—only then will it succeed. Otherwise, if the opponent possesses *di lian* skill, they will not be easily broken.

If struck on the back, the opponent will inevitably fall forward. Then, seal their right foot with your left, using the *Earth Dragon* ground-rising technique to strike their right leg with a left parry for victory.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
This is a "one counters two" maneuver. When lowering the body, precision is essential—if you collapse entirely to the ground, rising again will be difficult. Some say employing the Third Gate is even more effective: as the opponent uses the *Earth Dragon* rising technique, before they fully recover, stabilize your right step with *di lian* force, lift your left knee, and strike their left flank for victory.

**Right, Chapter Four:**
This is a "two counters one" maneuver. Strike precisely as they begin to rise but have not yet fully recovered. If the opponent lifts their left knee, I do not advance; instead, I follow their knee’s forward motion, collapsing outward and rolling the body to adopt the *Crouching Dragon* technique for victory.

**Right, Chapter Five:**
This method requires mastery of the *Earth Dragon* technique to be effective. Without it, the timing of rising and falling will be unclear, inviting only ridicule—how can one hope to prevail? After collapsing, one must gather spirit and *qi*, observing the opponent’s movements to launch an attack.

If the opponent, seeing my position, advances with a low stance and lifting force, I immediately use a left parry to deflect their left hand, then follow with my right hand to strike their chest for victory.

**Right, Chapter Six:**
This is a variation building on the previous stance, without profound meaning—only firmness and speed are required.

---

**Second Stance: Opponent Advances with Right Step and Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right step and lifting force, I use a left parry (*ge jin*), deflecting their right wrist outward from within. I then advance with my right *di lian*, sealing their right step from without, and apply a right seizing force (*qin jin*) to trap their Third Gate. The three forces must be applied simultaneously to prevail.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When executing this method, the left deflecting hand must be lifted with full force—this will naturally uproot their footing. Both hands and feet must advance together for optimal effect; otherwise, the opponent may retract their leg.

If the opponent throws me down, I immediately use my right foot’s hooking force (*gou jin*) to entangle their right foot, lowering my body into the full *Earth Dragon* stance. Pressing both hands to the ground and driving with my left foot’s *di* force, I strike their right shin, ensuring their defeat.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
When employing this method, the right leg must be sharply bent while the left leg remains fully extended—only then can the body’s *qi* be properly circulated for effectiveness.

If the opponent advances with lifting force and I retreat with a right step and parry, but their right hand has already withdrawn, my strike will miss. I then advance to entangle their left hand, lowering my body to attack their flank with the left Third Gate for victory.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
This is a variation for attacking downward. Strike swiftly as the opponent retreats, preventing their footwork from settling—this is the method of exploiting emptiness.

---

**Third Stance: Opponent Advances with Right Step and Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right step and lifting force, I stealthily advance a small left step, using a left sweeping force (*lüe jin*) to lift their right hand while keeping my body still. If they strike with their left hand, I seize the moment of their extension, swiftly twisting my body to crouch within the Inner Gate, gathering force to attack their flank with the left Third Gate for victory.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When advancing the left step, the posture must already be primed for attack—only by concealing intent will its subtlety be revealed.

---

**Fourth Stance: Opponent Advances with High Right Step and Sweeping Force**

When the opponent advances with a high right step and sweeping force, I use a right parry to deflect upward, then advance my left step to intercept and seize them.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method requires the left *di lian* to be firmly grounded to secure victory; otherwise, against a strong opponent, both may collapse together. If the opponent seals my body with their left step and attacks with a pulling force (*ba jin*), I twist my body and strike their inner knee with a firm knee force (*jian xi jin*).

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This is a method for countering upward. Strike precisely as the opponent advances with their left step—if they seize you first, escape will be impossible.

If the opponent attacks my left knee with a firm knee force, I swiftly shift my left step outward, lowering my body to anchor my neck and strike their right flank with my nape.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
This is a "one counters two" maneuver. The entire body’s stance must be stabilized, using a compact body technique to attack—only then will it be effective.

---

**Fifth Stance: Opponent Advances with High Stance and Dual-Handed Upper Attack**

When the opponent advances with a high stance and attacks my upper body with both hands, I use my left hand to coil downward and trap their left hand, and my right hand to coil downward and trap their right hand. Stealthily advancing my left step, I surge forward with my body to strike their chest with chest force (*xiong jin*).

**Right, Chapter One:**
This is a method for attacking the opponent with the entire body—do not confine it to chest force alone. If the opponent attacks from below, this method may still be used, but the hands must coil downward. When sealing the opponent’s hands, ensure they are firmly trapped to prevent withdrawal and counterattacks.

**When the opponent seals both my hands with theirs and attacks with chest force (*xiong jin*), leaving me unable to move my hands and with no time to delay—for even the slightest hesitation will allow the opponent to prevail—I must stealthily raise my right knee to strike upward into their groin and secure victory.**

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This is the *firm-knee groin lift* (*jianxi liaoyin*). It must be applied with careful judgment, for excessive force may endanger life. Exercise utmost caution.

---

**Sixth Stance: Opponent Advances with High Stance and Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a high stance and delivers a right-step lifting force (*liao jin*), I use my right *blocking force* (*ge jin*) to cast upward and deflect their right hand, then employ my left *bottom-refining force* (*dilian jin*) below to seal their right step. Twisting my body, I strike with *Three Gates force* (*sanmen jin*) to prevail.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method requires mobilizing the *qi* of the entire body, keeping the shoulders and back aligned, and attacking with short force. Without waiting for the opponent to employ *Three Gates force*, I press my right hand against their right hand, intercept their left step, then cast their right hand with my left. Executing all three forces simultaneously, I throw them to the right.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
The timing of this method must be neither too early nor too late. If applied too soon, the opponent will retreat in alarm; if too late, I will miss the moment to act. It must be deployed precisely as their momentum arises.

If the opponent attempts to shift their foot, I swiftly cast their right wrist with my right hand and their right elbow with my left, while using my left foot to seal their right step, throwing them to the left.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
This variation attacks downward, adapting the opponent’s method by shifting it to the left. When throwing, their arm must be bent against their chest.

---

**Seventh Stance: Opponent Assumes Horse-Riding Stance and Delivers Right Lifting Force**

When the opponent adopts a horse-riding stance and delivers a right lifting force, I immediately shift my step to the right, using my hands to drive my entire body forcefully toward the ground. Rising with the momentum, I employ a compact body method to strike their abdomen with both hands.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method requires angling the body to attack their flank diagonally upward, seizing my solidity to exploit their emptiness.

---

**Eighth Stance: Opponent Delivers Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent delivers a right-step lifting force, I use my left *firm-bone* (*jiangu*) to intercept their hand from inside to outside, then rotate my entire body. With my left foot, I coil their right step from outside to inside, and strike their chest with left *blocking force*, employing all three forces in unison.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method demands short force above and below. If long force is used, the opponent may be defeated, but I will not emerge unscathed.

If the opponent advances with their left step intending to block, I withdraw my right hand and step back with my left, coiling their left step from outside to inside. Then, I seize their right ribs with my left hand and drag outward with both forces.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This is the method of returning upward. It requires clear evasion, first establishing an unassailable position. When executing the right *seizing force*, the entire body’s *qi* must be mobilized.

---

**Ninth Stance: Opponent Delivers Low Right-Hand Lifting Force**

When the opponent delivers a low right-hand lifting force, I advance with my right *firm-bone force* to seal their hand. Then, I grasp their hair with my left hand and seize their chin with my right, employing both forces simultaneously.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method contains true subtlety. Do not use excessive force. When sealing their hand, coil their step from the outer gate with your right foot to prevent their retreat.

If the opponent advances with a high right step and lifting force, I move from the outer gate inward, using my right *blocking force* to deflect their hand. Seizing the moment, I advance my left step and hook their nose bridge from behind their chest with my left hand, applying my entire body’s skill to snap their neck backward.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This is a variation of the previous method. When applying it, ensure the neck is bent toward the opponent’s chest—never to the left, or they will slip free.

---

**Tenth Stance: Opponent Delivers Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent delivers a right-step lifting force, I advance my left step with *bottom-refining force* to seal their right foot from outside to inside. Then, I advance my left hand from above to cast their right hand downward, using force to drag it down. Following this, I advance my right hand from above to strike diagonally at their neck.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When casting their hand, if they resist with upward force, making it difficult to drag downward, I instead lift their right hand from below and flip it upward, then advance my right hand to strike their face.

If the opponent advances their right hand to strike while my hand is already cast and difficult to withdraw, I crouch inward, advance my left step into a kneeling position, and drive my right hand into their chest with the entire body’s force.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
When dropping the left step, evade the opponent’s right hand to establish an unassailable position, ensuring the knee bears force.

If the opponent attempts to strike my chest, I withdraw both hands, then collapse to the ground. Assuming the *Earth Dragon* (*dilong*) posture, I propel my body forward with full force, using my right foot to sweep their right foot.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
When lunging, the spine must be forcefully lowered, the right foot acting as a step while the left leg extends straight, then sharply bent inward to maximize force.

If the opponent sweeps my right foot, causing me to fall backward, I do not wait for them to rise. Instead, I roll to the side, pressing both hands to the ground, and employ the *Earth Dragon* posture to rise, striking their left shin with my left foot.

**Right, Chapter Four:**
This method requires full extension, striking downward with the left foot from above.

---

**Eleventh Stance: Opponent Delivers Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent delivers a right-step lifting force, I immediately crouch backward, pressing both hands to the ground. Assuming the *Earth Dragon* posture, I swing my right leg upward from above to strike their shin.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When applying this method, mobilize the *qi* of the entire body and attack with *firm-bone force*. If the right hand misses, roll the body and strike with the left heel from inside to outside, also employing an upward-to-downward motion.

**Twelfth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I step forward with my right foot, sweeping their hand from inside to outside. Then, I reverse and step forward with my left foot, pressing my back against their chest from below. Crouching, I use both hands to seize their right foot, employing the *Central Full Stance* to crush their knee.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When applying this method, ensure close adherence to prevent their retreat. The left step must be precisely measured so their right foot is exposed before you. When crushing the knee, direct their kneecap upward to shatter the bone—do not allow their *Weizhong* point to face upward, lest I lose leverage.

If the opponent seeks to crush my knee, I immediately seize their hair, using my left hand to forcefully grip their chin. Employing the *Full-Back Stance*, I break their neck with full-body force.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This must be executed the moment their grasp is unstable. Since their hands target the lower body, I exploit their upper vulnerability—victory is assured. However, if their movement is too swift, I may be unable to react.

---

**Thirteenth Stance: Opponent Wields Blade for a Frontal Thrust**

When the opponent thrusts a blade toward my face, I must not retreat. Swiftly sidestepping, I advance my left foot and use my left hand to parry their right wrist from outside to inside. Then, I strike upward with my right hand to their face.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method may also employ the middle and index fingers to pierce their nostrils or strike their eyes—adapt based on the urgency of the situation.

---

**Fourteenth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I seize their hand with my left, crouch, and use my right hand to hook their right shin. As I lift, I twist their shin with both hands, then drive forward with my full-body force to strike them.

**Right, Chapter One:**
Whether hooking with the left hand or targeting either leg, the principle remains the same.

---

**Fifteenth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I step forward with my right foot, crouch, and use both hands to seal their right foot. I attack their *Tiger-Shin Bone* with *Three-Gate Force*.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When sealing both feet, ensure thorough defense to prevent the opponent from seizing the opportunity to kick my face.

If the opponent seals my right foot and prepares to attack with *Three-Gate Force*, I strike their right ribs with my right knee as their foot descends.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
If overpowered and thrown, I must not use my knee—instead, I kick upward with my right foot.

---

**Sixteenth Stance: Opponent Delivers Right-Step Sweeping Force**

When the opponent delivers a right-step sweeping force, I twist their right hand upward with both hands, step forward with my right foot to seal their right foot from outside to inside, and hurl them leftward with my full-body *qi*.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method requires wrenching their right wrist with all force to break their momentum. It may be applied to both inner and outer gates—if used on the inner gate, seal with the left foot from inside to outside.

---

**Seventeenth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I also step forward with my right foot, using *Blocking Force* to deflect their hand. Following through, I seize their shoulder, then grasp their heel with my left hand and hurl them outward with my full-body force.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When applying this method, step into the opponent’s inner gate. The *Blocking Force* must rise from below and overturn from within the abdomen.

If thrown by the opponent, my chest must not touch the ground. Instead, I press both hands to the earth, assume the *Earth Dragon’s* side posture, and strike their groin with a flying right hand.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
The flying kick employs the *Earth Dragon’s* turning motion—though it lacks profound intent, mastery of the *Earth Dragon* technique is essential.

---

**Eighteenth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I neither advance nor retreat. Instead, I root my left foot firmly, then kick upward with my right leg, driving my full-body force straight into their chest.

**Right, Chapter One:**
This method is effective only for those with skill. The left foot must be rooted to defend, and the right foot must be rooted to strike—otherwise, victory is uncertain.

If the opponent strikes my ribs with their right foot, I do not retreat. Instead, I root both feet firmly, using my chest and ribs to drive outward and strike their foot.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This method demands even greater skill—students must not imitate it carelessly.

---

**Nineteenth Stance: Opponent Delivers Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent delivers a right-step lifting force, I shift my entire body to evade their hand. Following the momentum, I step forward with my right foot and use my right hand’s *Blocking Force* to intercept their waist. Then, I seize their hair with my left hand and forcefully break their neck downward.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When blocking, the motion must descend from above. Step into the opponent’s inner gate to prevent their retreat. For those with skill, a horizontal block to their right hand, pinning it at the waist, is even more effective.

---

**Twentieth Stance: Opponent Advances with Right-Step Lifting Force**

When the opponent advances with a right-step lifting force, I crouch and first bind their heel with my left hand, then use my right hand to sweep their knee outward with force.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When sweeping the knee, target the inner side—sweeping the kneecap will fail.

If the opponent crouches to strike my knee, I also crouch, step forward with my left foot, and kneel to strike their back from above with my full-body force.

**Right, Chapter Two:**
This exploits their upper vulnerability—most effective.

If the opponent attempts to crouch and strike my back, I do not wait for them to complete their stance. Instead, I drive upward with my full-body force, attacking their chest and abdomen with *Second- and Third-Gate Force*.

**Right, Chapter Three:**
Whenever crouching to enter the lower path, if the opponent targets my upper body, this method may be applied.

**Twenty-First Technique:**
When the opponent advances in *Horse-Riding Stance* with a right sweeping force, I step forward with my right foot, sealing their right hand from outside to inside. Using my left hand, I cast off their right hand and tuck it beneath my flank, then twist my body to strike their neck with my right hand.

**Right, Chapter One:**
Step forward with the right foot, entering the inner gate. If the upper path is blocked by the opponent’s left hand, immediately use *Firm Knee Force* to seize their inner knee in the lower path.

**Twenty-Second Technique:**
When the opponent strikes from *Horse-Riding Stance* with a right upward force, I seal their right hand from above with my left hand, then sidestep and advance to execute a *Low Refinement Slash* against their instep.

**Right, Chapter One:**
When using *Low Refinement*, ensure the *Yongquan* point has an inward momentum—only then does the "slash" achieve its meaning.

I adapt my methods to their structure, never missing the moment nor advancing recklessly. This is the essential tactic in facing an opponent, and only through mastering *Spirit-Mobilizing Skill* can one grasp its subtlety.

**Miscellaneous Commentaries on *Neigong Scattered Gates***

**First Saying:**
Master Nanxi devoted over twelve years to his practice, compiling countless hand techniques. Yet these *Neigong Scattered Gates* distill his synthesis of various schools’ methods, refined through the *Internal Skill Classic*, discarding the superfluous to retain only those with natural overcoming intent, then established as formal patterns to share with fellow practitioners.

**Second Saying:**
The high and low postures, inner and outer reversals, and rules of *Neigong Scattered Gates* are all ancient fixed methods; modern practitioners may not alter them. As for the seamless, naturally fitting combat joints within—these arose from Nanxi’s insights while studying the *Internal Skill Classic*, later refined by his own ingenuity. Those who have not read the *Internal Skill Classic* cannot comprehend them.

**Third Saying:**
The orthodox and variant forms of *Neigong Scattered Gates* were all personally written by Master Nanxi. Only the annotations in the orthodox forms were composed by Jingfang, yet even these were based on the *Internal Skill Classic* and Nanxi’s daily discourses before he dared put brush to paper.

**Fourth Saying:**
The appended *Divided Verses* in *Neigong Scattered Gates* were transmitted orally by Nanxi’s teacher, while the annotations to the *Eight Verses* were personally written by Nanxi himself.

**Fifth Saying:**
*Neigong Scattered Gates* comprises the orthodox forms, forty-five variant hands, twenty-four general hands, and eight hands—seventy-seven methods in total, covering upper and lower, left and right, front and back, inner and outer. If one trains these thoroughly, no matter from which direction an opponent attacks, there will always be a method to overcome them. Thus, there is no need to exhaust all possibilities.

**Sixth Saying:**
Anyone with even slight familiarity with the patterns and syntax of *Neigong Scattered Gates* can gain insight through careful reflection. Yet to grasp its divine subtleties, one must first study the *Internal Skill Classic*.

**Seventh Saying:**
Only after awakening through the *Internal Skill Classic* should one study *Scattered Gates*. If one cannot awaken to the *Internal Skill Classic* but receives clear transmission of *Neigong Scattered Gates* from an enlightened teacher, and then dedicates time and effort to refining it, victory can still be achieved—one need not be rigidly bound to awakening through the *Internal Skill Classic*.

**Eighth Saying:**
*Neigong Scattered Gates* contains peerlessly exquisite hand methods, and its unfathomable wonders lie within the variant forms. Yet without first mastering the orthodox forms, the practitioner cannot glimpse the divine transformations of the variants.

**Ninth Saying:**
In learning *Neigong Scattered Gates*, the first priority is to recognize where *force* resides. Where the opponent’s *force* lies is what they rely upon. If I know their reliance and break it, how can they not be defeated?

**Tenth Saying:**
The second priority is to recognize where the opponent has no *force*. Where they lack *force* is where they fear attack. If I know their fear and strike there, how can they not be defeated?

**Eleventh Saying:**
The third priority is to recognize where the opponent establishes their *gate*. Where they set their *gate* is their trap for me. If I know their trap and avoid it, how can they prevail?

**Twelfth Saying:**
The fourth priority is to recognize where the opponent has no *gate*. Where there is no *gate* is where they are helpless. If I know their helplessness and attack there, how can they prevail?

**Thirteenth Saying:**
One must first understand the principles of the body’s joints—backward and forward, yielding and resisting, opening and closing, horizontal and vertical—before one can know *force* and *gate*.

**Fourteenth Saying:**
Only by thoroughly mastering the principles of the body’s joints—backward and forward, yielding and resisting, opening and closing, horizontal and vertical—can one accurately discern *force* and *gate* without error.

**Fifteenth Saying:**
Without understanding the principles of the body’s joints—backward and forward, yielding and resisting—no matter how much苦功 one expends, one is merely learning *Scattered Gates*, not *Neigong Scattered Gates*.

**Sixteenth Saying:**
Why does training *Neigong Scattered Gates* with *rooted strength* yield no effect? It must be that one uses *rooted* but not *strength*. If one truly employs *rooted strength*, how could there be no effect?

**Seventeenth Saying:**
Why does training *Neigong Scattered Gates* with *firm knees* yield no effect? It must be that one uses *knees* but not *firmness*. If one truly employs *firm knees*, how could there be no effect?

**Eighteenth Saying:**
Why, in learning *Neigong Scattered Gates*, does one not understand the use of *inner crotch* and *outer hip* *force*?

**Response:**
It must be that one has not read the *Neigong Classic*. If one has read the *Neigong Classic*, there would be none who do not understand the use of *force* in the *outer hip* and *inner crotch*.

**Nineteenth Saying:**
Why, in learning *Neigong Scattered Gates*, can one not use the *shoulder*, *back*, *chest*, and *ribs* to control others?
It must be that one does not understand *adhering force* and *sweating force*. If one employs *adhering force* and *sweating force*, there would be none who cannot use the *shoulder*, *back*, *chest*, and *ribs* to control others.

**Twentieth Saying:**
Why, in learning *Neigong Scattered Gates*, does one not understand the *source of force*, the *reason for adhering knees*, or the *purpose of firming the root and refining*?
This must be because one has not deeply embodied the *Neigong Classic*. If one deeply embodies the *Neigong Classic*, how could such flaws exist?

**Twenty-First Saying:**
If one does not know the *Neigong Classic* but only learns *Scattered Gates*, can one still achieve victory?
In *Neigong Scattered Gates*, there are *skillful stances* and *clever stances*. *Skillful stances* cannot be employed without knowing the *Neigong Classic*. As for *clever stances*, if one merely understands the principles of the body’s joints—backward and forward, yielding and resisting, opening and closing, horizontal and vertical—one can achieve victory without being entirely constrained by *Neigong*.

**Twenty-Second Saying:**
If one has gained understanding in *internal force* and is also proficient in *Scattered Gates*, what then?
*Neigong* combined with *Scattered Gates*—hardness tempers softness, softness tempers hardness. The transformations of *generation* and *overcoming*, *yin* and *yang*, *emptiness* and *fullness*—one appears as a gentle maiden at a glance, yet seizes like a fierce tiger. Its marvel is beyond description.

**Twenty-Third Saying:**
Why, when studying *Neigong Scattered Gates*, does one open the scroll and remain bewildered, unable to grasp its marvels?
It must be that one has not received instruction from an enlightened master. For any profound text, without guidance from an enlightened master, one will inevitably remain bewildered. Let Jingfang speak a word or two of it, and none will fail to deeply comprehend it in their hearts.

**Twenty-Fourth Saying:**
Without instruction from an enlightened master, can one still grasp a thing or two?
Without instruction from an enlightened master, if one reads diligently and reflects deeply, practices with a partner, and possesses exceptional intelligence, after prolonged effort, one may suddenly awaken. However, compared to having an enlightened master’s guidance, it requires a hundredfold more effort.

**Twenty-Fifth Saying:**
If an intelligent person studies *Neigong Scattered Gates* for a long time, they must awaken—otherwise, what value would this book hold?

**Twenty-Sixth Saying:**
In learning *Neigong Scattered Gates*, is there anyone who awakens at first sight?
Those who claim to awaken at first sight either deceive others or deceive themselves. Jingfang possesses only mediocre talent, yet after five or six years of personal guidance from Nanxizi, what I have gained is but one ten-thousandth of his knowledge. If there were one who awakened at first sight, Jingfang would flatly declare: they either deceive others or deceive themselves.

**Twenty-Seventh Saying:**
Is learning *Neigong Scattered Gates* truly so difficult?
To speak of its subtlety and marvel, it is indeed not easy. But to speak of overcoming an opponent, it is most suitable for people. Try applying it, and you will surely witness extraordinary results—it only requires three months of diligent practice.

**Twenty-Eighth Saying:**
The hand techniques in *Neigong Scattered Gates* differ greatly from those of the world.
We are all human, all with the same body—what difference could there be? Yet in the subtle distinctions of the body’s joints—backward and forward, yielding and resisting, opening and closing, horizontal and vertical—the outcomes of victory and defeat diverge vastly.

**Twenty-Ninth Saying:**
In *Neigong Scattered Gates*, whenever one uses the feet, the entire body must fall to the ground, never lightly standing high to strike with the foot—this is the peculiarity of this school. Yet when facing those in the world who stand high and strike with the foot, practitioners of *Neigong* can cause them to lift their foot without rising. This is a natural marvel, and Jingfang does not understand why.

**Thirtieth Saying:**
Those who have studied this Dao in the past—whether blindly arrogant or timid and weak, or deeply secretive and stingy, swearing never to teach others—yet Nanxizi alone conducts himself with scholarly elegance, treats others with humility, and to all who sincerely seek instruction, explains its principles without reserve. Jingfang has engraved this in his heart—does the world hear my words and also admire him?

**Eight Secrets of Nanxizi of Shanzuo for Overcoming Opponents in Combat**

**Eight Secrets:**
*Preparation, Assessment, Enticement, Provocation, Exhaustion, Confusion, Pursuit, Adaptation.*

**Method of Preparation:**
The first essential secret in facing an opponent is *preparation*.
Only by knowing one’s own preparedness can one respond to an opponent’s attack. Only by observing an opponent’s lack of preparedness can one exploit their flaws. The meaning of *preparation* is vast indeed.
In terms of *gongfu*, within advancing lies *retreat force*—this is preparation for the opponent’s pull. Within retreating lies *advance force*—this is preparation for the opponent’s collision. Within vertical force lies *horizontal force*—this is preparation for the opponent’s blocking and sweeping. Within horizontal force lies *vertical force*—this is preparation for the opponent’s gaps.
In terms of *Scattered Gates*, when striking the opponent’s upper path, one must first prepare for their strike to one’s lower path. When striking the opponent’s inner gate, one must first prepare for their strike to one’s outer gate. Drawing out and extending, one dares not advance lightly—this is preparation for the opponent’s enticement. One dares not act hastily—this is preparation for the opponent’s provocation. One dares not move repeatedly—this is preparation for the opponent’s exhaustion. The applications of *preparation* are boundless. Truly, it is the essential Dao of self-defense and the secret technique of attacking an opponent.

**Method of Assessment:**
The second essential secret in facing an opponent is *assessment*.
By assessing the depth of the opponent’s skill, one can control their vital points. By ensuring the opponent cannot assess one’s depth, one avoids being toyed with by them. The meaning of *assessment* is far-reaching indeed.
Assess the opponent’s distance to determine advance and retreat. Assess the opponent’s emptiness and fullness to apply *Scattered Gates*. Assess the opponent’s strength and weakness to employ hardness and softness. Employ many methods to assess them, and only then engage in combat.

The opponent may be enticed to assess their knowledge, provoked to gauge their composure, wearied to test their strength, or adapted to to discern their adaptability. Such is the method of *assessment*—applicable in all circumstances and indispensable at the outset of an encounter.

**Method of Enticement:**
The third essential secret in facing an opponent is *enticement*.
When meeting an opponent of comparable strength, where techniques are evenly matched and both parties are well-versed, each guards their own body.
If I do not covet the opponent’s flaws, I must ensure no flaws are exposed to them; if the opponent does not covet my flaws, they will not expose any to me. Thus, with no flaws for the opponent to exploit and no desire in them to strike, no opportunity arises for me to employ my attacking techniques.
Therefore, true flaws must never exist, but false flaws must never be absent. If neither side exposes flaws nor harbors greed, how can victory or defeat be determined?
The method lies in feigning a vulnerable opening for the opponent. If they greedily strike at it, they will inevitably leave themselves unguarded—whereupon I strike unexpectedly.
Thus, to strike the opponent’s inner gate, one must first entice their outer gate; to strike their lower path, one must first entice their upper path. To employ hardness, first display softness; to employ emptiness, first display fullness; to employ fullness, first display emptiness.
Though these principles are clear and easily understood, without prior training, they may not be readily applied in the moment.

**Method of Provocation:**
The fourth essential secret in facing an opponent is *provocation*.
This is not provocation through words, but through action.
Enticement tests the opponent with emptiness, while provocation moves them with substance. If the opponent remains unmoved by enticement, how else can they be engaged?
One must feign anger, press close to their body, and test their courage or timidity while observing their movements—only then can one’s attacking techniques be deployed.
Thus, provoke their left, and they cannot but turn left to meet you; provoke their right, and they cannot but turn right to meet you—thereby revealing their true disposition.
The subtleties herein must be deeply contemplated; do not cling to the vulgar notion of "provoking a general." These techniques, when used to elicit the opponent’s intent, become strikes; when used to probe their intent, they are called provocation.
In sum, the hands act with substance while the intent remains empty.

**Method of Fatigue:**
The fifth essential secret in facing an opponent is *fatigue*.
To fatigue is to exhaust, to sicken, to induce slackness—then attack.
Within a single day, one’s *qi* is sharp at dawn but sluggish by dusk; within a single hour, it is sharp at the outset but sluggish by the end. At the first movement, one’s *qi* is inevitably sharp, and sharpness brings fierce strength. Yet if movement continues unceasingly, *qi* must slacken, and slackness leads to decline—this is the natural course.
When facing a strong opponent who seeks to press the attack, I must gather my entire body’s strength to await them. If they attempt to retreat, I use my spirit to disrupt their rhythm, employing emptiness within fullness, fullness within emptiness, softness concealing hardness, or hardness concealing softness—all to deny them respite. Only when they grow weary from prolonged movement do I strike.
Yet when employing fatigue, one must cherish one’s own spirit and conserve one’s strength, reserving it to attack the opponent. Otherwise, after prolonged exertion, the opponent may be fatigued, but how can one remain sharp alone?

**Method of Confusion:**
The sixth essential secret in facing an opponent is *confusion*.
Confusion is the blinding of the eyes, the bewilderment of the mind. If I am not confused by the opponent, how can they defeat me? If the opponent is not confused by me, how can I outwit them? Between confusion and clarity, victory and defeat are decided.
Thus, when facing a strong opponent, one must employ many means to confuse them: advancing while appearing uncertain to bewilder them, retreating while appearing unpredictable to bewilder them.
Conceal one’s weaknesses and refrain from using them; employ one’s strengths to take the initiative—this is the method of confounding the foolish.
Hide one’s strengths to inflate their arrogance; flaunt one’s weaknesses to lull their vigilance—this is the method of confounding the wise.
Feign disorder, adopt bizarre postures, display softness when intending to use hardness, or test with hardness when intending to use softness—all serve to confuse.
Once this technique is applied, no opponent will escape with eyes unblinded and mind unbewildered. It surpasses the method of fatigue, for fatigue merely attacks their strength, while confusion strikes directly at their mind.

**Method of Pursuit:**
The seventh essential secret in facing an opponent is *pursuit*.
When the opponent has been fatigued by my techniques, their strength slackens; when confused by my techniques, their mind grows careless. Reckless and careless, they no longer wish to fight. If not now, when shall their will be subdued?
Thus, the method of pursuit: press close to scatter their gates, or maintain distance to employ spiritual movement.
If the opponent retreats with horizontal force, pursue with vertical; if they retreat with vertical force, pursue with horizontal.
Pursue slowly to guard against deception, or swiftly to exploit their emptiness. The methods of pursuit are manifold, yet all deny the opponent freedom of movement.
To pursue when opportunity arises and retreat when difficulty looms—this is wisdom.
Mastering these techniques reveals the subtleties of pursuit.
Yet there is also the method of pursuing while striking, attacking the opponent’s unpreparedness; and pursuing without striking, awaiting their flaws—both must be understood.

**Method of Adaptation:**
The eighth essential secret in facing an opponent is *adaptation*.
The subtleties of adaptation are beyond words.

Adapting to things by entrusting them to their nature, achieving success by seizing the moment, and applying techniques according to the opponent—since ancient times, the ceaseless responsiveness of heaven and humanity has arisen from nothing but the subtlety of *adaptation*. As the *Yijing* states: "Transformation and movement never abide; they circulate without emptiness." Even the deployment of formations in the *Sanmen* school of unarmed combat does not stray from this single principle.

For if one seeks to control the opponent with fixed techniques, the opponent’s variations are infinite while one’s methods are finite; but if one establishes techniques in response to the opponent, then when the opponent has no fixed form, one’s techniques likewise become formless. How profound is the meaning of *adaptation*!

If the opponent seeks to attack my upper path, I adapt to their upward momentum and counterattack—this is the method of Chapter Two in the Twentieth Scenario. If they attack my lower path, I adapt to their downward momentum and counterattack—this is the method of Chapter Four in the First Scenario. If their assault is fierce, I adapt to its ferocity and devise a counter—this is the method of Chapter Two in the Fifth Scenario. If they throw me to the ground, I adapt to their throw and establish a counter—this is the method of Chapter Four in the Tenth Scenario.

In sum, when I apply my skill, countless established techniques reside in my mind. The methods of the ancients are consummate, and I cannot transcend their bounds; thus, I must rely on these established forms as my compass. Yet if no fixed technique resides in my mind, I devise methods in response to the opponent’s *qi*, their openings, and their momentum—techniques that cannot be confined to a single form.

Ah! Only when one grasps this profound principle may one be deemed worthy of witnessing the inner workings of the *Sanmen* school.

**The Authentic Complete Edition of *Neigong Zhenjing* (True Classic of Internal Cultivation)**
*Annotated by Wang Nanxi, Collated by Zong Jingfang*

*The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation* (*Neigong Sijing*), as a specialized treatise on the practice of internal martial arts, has garnered significant attention among martial circles due to the fervent advocacy of Song Shirong, a master of Xingyi Quan. However, the various editions of *The Four Classics* currently in circulation have been subject to additions and omissions, lacking systematic coherence, thereby hindering later scholars from grasping its full essence. The "Original Transmission Martial Arts Dissemination Center" in Handan, Hebei, has generously made public its held authentic handwritten copy of *The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation*, hoping to aid readers in gaining a comprehensive and objective understanding of this martial arts text.

The original manuscript comprises over forty thousand characters. The table of contents at the beginning outlines the following structure:
- **Volume One**: *Neigong Jing* (Classic of Internal Cultivation)
- **Volume Two**: *Nagua Jing* (Classic of Absorbing the Trigrams)
- **Volume Three**: *Shenyun Jing* (Classic of Spirit Circulation), *Dali Zhujie* (Annotations on Great Strength), *Hezhan Bamen* (Eight Gates of Combined Combat)
- **Volume Four**: *Dilong Jing* (Classic of Earthly Dragon), *Sanmen Zhengju* (Standard Forms of Scattered Gates), *Sanmen Bianju* (Variations of Scattered Gates), *Sanmen Zongju* (General Principles of Scattered Gates), *Sanmen Zaping* (Miscellaneous Critiques of Scattered Gates), *Zhisheng Bajue* (Eight Secrets of Victory)

Regarding the provenance of this text, Ren Erqi (1877–1945), a disciple of the Song family’s Xingyi Quan, briefly recounted in his *Original Postscript to The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation*: "This book was obtained during the early Qing dynasty, retrieved by Minister Wang from a stone casket at the riverbed."

In the *Preface* by Wang Nanxi and the *Postscript* by Zong Jingfang included in this *Authentic Complete Edition of the True Classic of Internal Cultivation*, the detailed history of the text and Wang Nanxi’s painstaking research are elaborated. Wang Nanxi states:

> "*The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation* was acquired by my ancestor, Minister Wang, while serving in Jiangxi. After his passing, over a hundred years elapsed without anyone understanding the purpose of this book. In the year *jiazi*, I chanced upon it in a hidden storeroom. Upon opening it, I was at first bewildered and nearly abandoned my efforts. Later, after years of exhaustive study, I came to realize that this book embodies the foundational lineage of martial arts and the true transmission of internal cultivation."

Zong Jingfang recounts:

> "My friend Nanxi’s ancestor was a minister in the early Qing dynasty. While overseeing affairs in Jiangxi, his boat anchored at Qingjiang, where he witnessed a merchant’s vessel capsize. As goods were salvaged from the riverbed, a stone casket was recovered, containing two books. The minister wished to examine them. The merchant presented them for his inspection: one titled *Jiandan* (Sword Elixir), the other *Neigong* (Internal Cultivation). The *Neigong* text comprised four sections: *Neigong Jing* (Classic of Internal Cultivation), *Nagua Jing* (Classic of Absorbing the Trigrams), *Shenyun Jing* (Classic of Spirit Circulation), and *Dilong Jing* (Classic of Earthly Dragon). A postscript read: ‘Copied on the fifteenth day of the third month in the second year of Zhenguan.’ The minister purchased it at a high price."

Zong Jingfang, a friend of Wang Nanxi, studied *The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation* alongside him and assisted in "providing detailed annotations to elucidate its meaning, ensuring that later generations may study and apply it." For this publication, the editor has followed the original manuscript’s markings, distinguishing the *Four Classics* text (in bold) from the annotations (in regular script). As the original is a handwritten copy with somewhat cursive script, any errors in transcription or misinterpretation in this edition await correction by discerning readers.

**Preface and Postscript to *The Authentic Complete Edition of the True Classic of Internal Cultivation***

**Volume One**: *Neigong Jing* (Classic of Internal Cultivation)
**Volume Two**: *Nagua Jing* (Classic of Absorbing the Trigrams)

**Volume Four**: *Dilong Jing* (Classic of Earthly Dragon, comprising *Scattered Gates: Orthodox Formations*, *Scattered Gates: Variable Formations*, *General Critique*, *Miscellaneous Critiques*, *Twelve Patterns*, and *Eight Keys to Victory*)

**Preface**
*The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation* were acquired by my late ancestor, Grand Censor Wang, during his tenure in Jiangxi. After his passing, a century and more elapsed without anyone discerning the purpose of this work. By chance, in the *jiazi* year, I discovered it in the *Treasured Pavilion*. Upon opening the scroll, I was at first bewildered, nearly abandoning it in discouragement. Yet after years of painstaking study, I came to recognize this text as the foundational lineage of martial arts and the true transmission of internal skill. Once internal cultivation is mastered, every technique becomes a sublime application—what is called "drawing from an inexhaustible source, finding it wherever one turns."

However, the true transmission of internal cultivation does not seek haste; it demands years of dedicated effort before attainment is possible. The *Classic of Internal Cultivation* thus stands as the highest priority. Some may be dull of talent, impatient with its subtleties, or constrained by poverty, unable to train daily. If they rush to penetrate its principles upon first encounter, will they not gaze in vain like one who faces the ocean yet gathers nothing? Therefore, I have compiled several chapters on external manifestations of internal skill: *Great Power: Complete Formations*, *Internal Skill in Combined Combat*, *Scattered Gates of Internal Skill*, *Reversal and Compliance*, *Inversion and Sequence*, and *Essential Points of the Internal Classics*. Through these, even beginners may grasp the underlying principles of the text.

As for postures and techniques, a few are recorded here, yet without understanding the *Internal Classics*, one will often err fundamentally in the principles of skeletal alignment, joint coordination, and the interplay of compliance and resistance. Alas! *The Four Classics of Internal Cultivation* have languished in obscurity for centuries. The traces of the ancients have faded, leaving no transmission. How can later students of this Way avoid misdirecting their efforts?

Written in the autumn of the *renwu* year, after discussing these matters with my friend Jingfang of Zhushan, and transmitted to the *Orchid Fragrance Study*. Here I set it down as a preface.

—Preface by Wang Nanxi of Langya

chunks.original_text: 道自得天地之精髓，阴阳之秘蕴者，必不磨灭于默默之中，非偶然也。 天必生奇人以知之，知之必着为书，不行于数百年之前，必行于数百年之后，必生一得书之人，不奇惜，必生一藏书之人，藏书之人不能行，必生人以力行之，不畏艰难，务求讲明古人真迹，以待于后世，又恐一人之力有所不能，尽而又生人以辅翼之，岂偶然哉。 呜呼，若此诸人或相待于数百年之后，或相遇于数百年之中，其中，离离合合亦奇矣。 余之友南溪子，其祖为清初总宪督抚江西，泊舟清江见有商人舟覆，拯货水底，获一石函，中有二书，公欲视之。 商人呈公阅视之，一曰剑丹，一曰内功。 内功之书正四篇，一曰内功经； 二曰纳卦经； 三曰神运经； 四曰地龙经，后记云：贞观二年三月十五日录。 公以重价购之，嗟呼，此书作于上古藏于水底，盛之石函，可谓遂年湮矣。 数百年埋没，而一旦传之于世，岂非此道之不可磨灭，而特生贾人以得之，总宪公以藏之哉。 公得视书简阅良久，见其理元妙，实正好之，然以贮，膺朝廷重命，方欲尽瘁，未暇研究。 公殁，遂为世传。 公之后人，大抵以文、功名为重，其不读书者，又留心于身家生计，皆论不及此，间有阅及之者，开卷茫然，遂以为无用之物，甚至王氏之子孙亦有不知家藏有此书者。 唯吾友南溪子，生而颖悟，总读书不至功名，玩心于诗书之间，毫无世俗输积之计。 一日忽得此书，见有印迹，叹曰：公神明人也，其不以重价沽无用之物也，明矣！ 此书必有弥意，但无有能知之者矣。 乃细心推测，见其有言卦者，一似易经注解，有言周身经脉者，一似医家脉络，有练神气者，一似道家丹书，推测至二三年，无以对其际。 后与管某闲谈，伊言其师拳术精勇，妙艺绝伦等得之于内功经，因询之曰：“内功经尚存呼？ ”管某曰：“此书失之久矣，邵师盖得之于口授者，不过经中十之二三。 ”南溪子忽然有悟，盖明公所得之书也！ 又取而阅之，忽然略有所醒悟，乃益加钻研，才知可以开人之智慧，其次，亦可以疗病壮身，而遇敌可制胜，犹其功之小者。 二年之后出而遇敌，无不制胜。 嗟呼，百年以此书为无用之物，不有南溪子以推测之，终属于无用乎！ 古云：“道为知己者传。 ”良不虚也！ 百余年之理埋没而一旦发挥其蕴奥，岂非此道之不可磨灭，而特生南溪子以彰明之哉。 然此道弥奥无穷，南溪子自以为所能者，不过十中之半。 恨无知己者，与之讲明而切究之。 欲终不传，又恐古人之宝书自此而没灭，甚为可惜。 以此十数年之功，苦蕴于中，未发于外，常忧忧不乐。 丙子余至其邑，与之甚者，以年相若而志相得。 余之视彼如兄，而彼视之吾如弟，久闻其精于武技，适触所好，因再三致诘。 而南溪子以交厚，绝不吝惜，因为余说大概。 初闻之，以为拳勇之粗术耳，既而与馆于近村，与之朝夕相见，闻其功夫有壮身疗病之效，因求而用之。 南溪子曰：“此功夫非一朝一夕之故，恐不能持久，无益而徒劳耳。 ”余力请之，遂授吾一二，余取用之数月未见功效，暗以为迂调，且将弃之。 南溪子曰：“吾言此功非朝夕之可及，君不信，而今何如哉？ ”余愧甚，又用数月，微有功效，甚喜，告南溪子曰：且请再益。

The Dao, which embodies the essence of Heaven and Earth and the hidden mysteries of yin and yang, cannot perish in obscurity—this is no mere coincidence. Heaven must raise extraordinary individuals to comprehend it, and those who comprehend it must commit it to writing. If such works do not circulate in the centuries before, they will surely circulate in the centuries after. There must arise one who obtains the book, not by chance, and another who preserves it. If the preserver cannot put it into practice, there must arise one who strives to do so, undaunted by hardship, determined to elucidate the true legacy of the ancients for posterity. Yet fearing that one person’s efforts may not suffice, others will inevitably emerge to assist—how could this be mere coincidence?

Alas! Such individuals may await one another across centuries or meet within them, their paths converging and diverging in wondrous ways. My friend, Nanxi Zi, had an ancestor who served as a high-ranking censor and governor of Jiangxi in the early Qing. While moored at Qingjiang, he witnessed a merchant’s boat capsize, and upon rescuing goods from the water, recovered a stone casket containing two books. The official wished to examine them, and the merchant presented them for his inspection. One was titled *Sword and Elixir*, the other *Internal Cultivation*. The latter comprised four scrolls: the *Classic of Internal Cultivation*, the *Classic of Absorbing the Trigrams*, the *Classic of Spirit Movement*, and the *Classic of Earthly Dragon*. A postscript read: “Copied on the fifteenth day of the third month, second year of Zhen’guan.” The official acquired them at a high price.

Alas! This book, composed in high antiquity and concealed beneath the waters in a stone casket, had endured untold years of obscurity. After centuries of burial, it suddenly resurfaced—was this not proof of the Dao’s indestructibility, that Heaven specially raised a merchant to retrieve it and an official to preserve it? The official studied the texts at length, recognizing their profound principles as truly exceptional. Yet burdened by his solemn duties to the court, he had no leisure to delve deeply. After his passing, the books entered wider circulation. His descendants, however, valued literary pursuits and official rank, while those indifferent to scholarship focused on family and livelihood. None paid heed to these works. Even those who chanced upon them found the contents baffling and dismissed them as useless. Some of the Wang family’s descendants were unaware such books existed in their household.

Only my friend Nanxi Zi, born with keen intelligence, though he did not pursue official success, delighted in poetry and literature, free from worldly calculations. One day, he chanced upon these books and noticed their seals. Sighing, he remarked: “This official was a man of discernment—clearly, he would not have paid a high price for worthless things. These books must hold profound meaning, though none now understand them.” He pored over them meticulously, noting passages on trigrams resembling *Yijing* commentaries, others on the body’s meridians akin to medical texts, and still others on refining spirit and qi like Daoist alchemical manuals. For two or three years, he pondered them deeply but could not fathom their full significance.

Later, while conversing idly with a man named Guan, he learned that Guan’s master had achieved unparalleled skill in martial arts, attributing it to the *Classic of Internal Cultivation*. Nanxi Zi inquired: “Does the *Classic of Internal Cultivation* still exist?” Guan replied: “It has long been lost. My master, Shao, learned it orally, retaining only two or three parts out of ten.” Suddenly, Nanxi Zi realized—this was the very book the official had acquired! He retrieved it and studied it anew, gaining fleeting insights. Redoubling his efforts, he gradually grasped its potential to awaken wisdom, and secondarily, to heal illness and strengthen the body. Even its martial applications were but minor benefits. After two years, he tested his skills against opponents and never failed to prevail.

Alas! For a century, this book had been deemed useless—had Nanxi Zi not devoted himself to deciphering it, would it not have remained so? As the ancients said: “The Dao is transmitted to those who truly understand it.” How true! A principle buried for over a hundred years was suddenly brought to light—was this not proof of the Dao’s indestructibility, that Heaven specially raised Nanxi Zi to illuminate it?

Yet the Dao’s depths are boundless. Nanxi Zi admitted his mastery extended to only half of its ten parts. Regretting the lack of a kindred spirit to discuss and refine it with him, he feared that if he withheld it entirely, the ancients’ treasure would vanish forever—a grievous loss. For over a decade, he bore this burden silently, his heart heavy with unease.

In the *bingzi* year, I visited his hometown, and we became close, our ages and aspirations aligned. He regarded me as an elder brother, and I, him as a younger brother. Having long heard of his martial prowess, I was drawn to it, and pressed him repeatedly for details. Moved by our deep friendship, he held nothing back, outlining the essentials. At first, I dismissed it as mere brute martial skill. Later, when we lodged in a nearby village and met daily, I learned of its benefits for healing and strengthening the body, and begged to learn it. Nanxi Zi cautioned: “This practice cannot be mastered in a day or a night. Without perseverance, it will be futile.” I insisted, and he taught me a few techniques. After months of practice with no results, I privately deemed it impractical and nearly abandoned it. Nanxi Zi said: “I warned you this was no quick endeavor—do you now believe me?” Ashamed, I persisted for several more months, and faint progress emerged. Overjoyed, I told Nanxi Zi: “Please, teach me more.”

chunks.original_text: 南溪子曰：不可因后用之，数月之间，忽然得奇效，平时所患结核至是痊愈，气力数倍于常，然后知南溪子不轻以授人者，非吝也，重此道也。 因再拜求教，又得纤微，总甚少之，然后知其为人不少以言辞，亦遂不请。 南溪子曰：“此功用气之处，只有一经，若误入旁门，伤人不浅。 ”余总闻之而未着意，授而用之，渐有所悟。 忽思天地间之术，莫非古人拟造之术，吾独不可杜撰乎？ 略有所增损，不数月忽得拘挛病窘甚，以告南溪子曰：“此道之为功也，不可贪多，不可太急，不可妄有增损，内所增损多与此正为者耳，不然吾弟岂有受专。 余惶恐无地，立誓悔过。 南溪子讲后其端的数月之后，拘挛之病遂已，自此彼以为是者，日夜以求之，彼以为非者，日夜以去之。 如是者二年，觉心中大有所悟，而气体间浩浩乎如囊日矣，余虽不言而心知，然相知之弥，每相忘于形骸。 南溪子未以为功，余亦未尝出一言相附也，每谈及此至忘寝食，而南溪子灼论风发，不后如问之与以少矣，如是又二年，南溪子忽授书二卷，而告余曰：此无上之宝书也，久欲传人之，未得其人，今观矣非风尘者，愿以此相赠，其一曰剑书，此仙家之丹经，非夙有慧根者不可转传，其二曰内功经，此能壮身疗病，多换气力，吾欲传于海内，公诸好可乎？ 余惊喜异常，投地再拜曰：此万金不易之术耳，羡之者非能不甚？ 而吾兄独以教弟，能对弟之弥。 劳神以教弟，弟难报大德，今又传以宝书，且以传世，吾兄之力恕而无所私也，何不可之有因。 备问书之始末，南溪子具告之曰，此书多有不解者，今欲与吾弟细加注解以明之，而后人得而用之矣。 余曰：数百年之埋没，而一旦传于海内，岂非此道之不可没灭哉，天特生一不畏艰辛之人，务求讲明古人真迹，以传后世也哉，弟岂不才，敢竭鄙诚以辅翼吾兄，共成此于是乎序。 珠山宗景房序 总论

Nanxi Zi said: "Do not assume that because you practiced for months and suddenly achieved extraordinary results—your long-standing lumps and swellings healed, your strength multiplied severalfold—only then did you understand that I did not lightly transmit this to others not out of stinginess, but out of reverence for this Dao."

Thereupon, I bowed again and sought further instruction. Though I gained some slight insights, they remained scant. Only then did I realize that Nanxi Zi was not one to speak idly, and so I ceased my requests. Nanxi Zi said: "In this practice, the method of employing qi follows but a single channel. Should one stray into side paths, the harm will be no small matter."

I heard these words but did not take them to heart. After receiving the instruction and practicing, I gradually began to comprehend. Suddenly, I thought: *Are not all arts under heaven but imitations devised by the ancients? Why should I alone not invent my own?* I made slight modifications, and within months, I was stricken with severe cramping and stiffness. I told Nanxi Zi: "The efficacy of this Dao lies in this: one must not be greedy for progress, nor rush too hastily, nor recklessly alter its methods. Most of the changes I made ran counter to its true principles—otherwise, how could I have suffered such affliction?"

I was overwhelmed with shame and immediately vowed to repent. Nanxi Zi explained the proper methods in detail, and after several months, my cramping and stiffness were cured. From then on, whatever he deemed correct, I pursued day and night; whatever he deemed incorrect, I abandoned day and night. Thus, for two years, I felt profound awakening in my heart, while my qi and body became as boundless as the rising sun. Though I did not speak of it, my heart knew the truth. The deeper our mutual understanding grew, the more we forgot our physical forms.

Nanxi Zi did not regard this as any great achievement, nor did I ever utter a word of flattery. Whenever we discussed these matters, we would forget sleep and food. Nanxi Zi’s discourses were incisive and eloquent, leaving little room for further questions. After another two years, Nanxi Zi suddenly presented me with two scrolls, saying: "These are supreme treasures. I have long wished to transmit them, but never found the right person. Now I see you are no mere drifter in the world of dust. I wish to bestow them upon you. The first is *The Sword Scroll*, a cinnabar classic of the immortals, which must not be passed on to those without innate wisdom. The second is *The Internal Cultivation Classic*, which strengthens the body, cures illness, and greatly enhances one’s qi and strength. I intend to spread it throughout the land—would you make it known to all who seek it?"

Overwhelmed with astonishment and joy, I prostrated myself and bowed again, saying: "This is a teaching beyond price—who would not yearn for it? Yet you alone have chosen to teach me. How can I ever repay your boundless kindness? Now you entrust me with these treasured scrolls, even permitting their transmission to future generations. Your generosity is selfless—how could I refuse?" I then asked about the origins of the texts in detail.

Nanxi Zi explained fully: "There are many passages in these scrolls that remain obscure. I wish to work with you to annotate and clarify them so that later generations may understand and apply them." I replied: "These texts, buried for centuries, are now to be spread across the land—is this not proof that this Dao cannot be extinguished? Heaven must have raised one who fears no hardship to elucidate the true methods of the ancients and transmit them to posterity. Though I am unworthy, I dare to pledge my humble sincerity to assist you, my brother, in completing this endeavor." Thus, this preface was written.

chunks.original_text: 拳勇之术，古来不下数十家，曰探马、曰鉴子、曰罗汉、曰太祖、曰佛爷、曰武子，一切可惊可骇之名难以尽述。 承人陋习，学此则非彼，学彼则非此，纷纷聚讼，日甚一日。 而要之不得内功真传，拘家所纵，费尽苦功，终属下乘。 犹之读书不能反约、泛览、博务，何能明道？ 又凡物莫不有其本，得其本而末随之矣。 所谓一以御万，简以御烦（繁）者也。 近来习此道者，忘其本之为一，而逐其末之不同，分门别户，捏造名色，往往自为誉曰：“吾之术近路也”。 不询其一以御万、简以御烦（繁）之道，茫然罔觉，何怪其临敌溃哉。 夫宇宙之正道，原未有近路也，不过有本末先后耳。 后此变化无方，皆前此循序渐进有以致之也，何有近路之可言哉？ 然则所谓本者何也？ 曰“”[注：为“筋”之异体字，但从上下文观之，此处凡用处，似应为“劲”字较妥，或许当时、筋、劲通用？ 然在以后的文中，也有、筋、劲同时出现的时候，看来又是有区别的。 何以如此待考，现一律依原文刊出]也。 顺进可以制敌，退可以自守，往来上下，无不如意。 松、小、背，不足以当敌，退不能自守，备多虚实，无非危机。 由此言之，固要哉。 然不知之纲领，不知之枢机，不知之归宿，虽有犹未尝也。 何谓之纲领？ 曰头也。 头为诸阳之会，一身之纲领也，譬如物之有柄，事之有始。 柄之不正，事之不裹，专望后之等哉？ 故头之为用也，欲向上提起，不欲向下堆积，欲生旺有神，不宜颓靡无气，一身之虽不在头，而头未始无关于之得失也； 何谓之枢机？ 曰肩也，肋也。 肩为臂之本，肋为气之窟，上以头部之精神，下以足腰胯之威势，周身之大关会也。 譬如室之有门，国之有关，门不开不通往来出入。 故肩之为用也，其要有八，曰通、透、穿、贴、松、汗、合、坚； 肋之为用也，其要有二，曰开张舒展，紧弹聚敛，得此窍诀，中部之妙思过半矣。 何为劲之归宿，曰足也。 足为百体之根，上载全身者也，譬如万物之生于土而履于地，衰旺体态无不因乎地。 苟非博厚，何能载物哉？ 故足为之出也。 凡一放一松，无不从足底涌泉穴而起，之入也，一收一紧，无不从足底涌泉穴而伏，此下路之要诀，而工夫之根基也。 知此三者，可以得其大概矣。 犹有要专何者也？

The arts of martial valor have numbered no fewer than dozens of schools since ancient times—Exploring Horse, Mirror Son, Arhat, Grand Ancestor, Buddha, Warrior Son—names so astonishing and fearsome they defy full recounting. Yet vulgar custom prevails: to study one is to reject another, to embrace one is to spurn the rest, and disputes multiply day by day. The crux lies in failing to inherit the true transmission of internal skill. Bound by sectarian dogma, practitioners exhaust themselves in vain toil, ever remaining in the lower ranks. It is like reading without returning to essentials, skimming without depth, or pursuing breadth without focus—how can one grasp the Dao?

All things possess a root; when the root is secured, the branches follow. This is what is meant by "one governing ten thousand" and "simplicity governing complexity." Yet those who practice this Way in recent times have forgotten that its root is singular, chasing instead the myriad differences of its branches. They divide into factions, fabricate names, and often boast, "My art is the shortcut." Ignorant of the principle of "one governing ten thousand" or "simplicity governing complexity," they wander in confusion—no wonder they crumble in combat.

The true Way of the cosmos has never offered shortcuts; there are only root and branch, before and after. Later transformations, boundless in variation, arise solely from gradual, orderly progress—where is there room for shortcuts?

Then what is this root? It is *jin*. When advancing, it can subdue the enemy; when retreating, it can defend the self. In all directions—up, down, forth, back—it responds as one wishes. *Jin* that is slack, weak, or hollow cannot withstand an opponent, nor can it guard the self in retreat. Every preparation, whether substantial or insubstantial, becomes a perilous moment. Thus, *jin* is indeed essential.

Yet without understanding the guiding principles of *jin*, its pivotal mechanisms, or its ultimate destination, one may possess *jin* in name but never in truth.

What are the guiding principles of *jin*? They lie in the head. The head is the meeting point of all yang, the guiding principle of the entire body—like the handle of an object or the beginning of an affair. If the handle is crooked, the matter cannot be resolved; how can one expect the rest to follow? Thus, the head’s function is to lift upward, not to sink downward; to be vibrant and spirited, not sluggish and lifeless. Though *jin* does not reside in the head, the head’s bearing is never irrelevant to the mastery or loss of *jin*.

What are the pivotal mechanisms of *jin*? They lie in the shoulders and ribs. The shoulders are the root of the arms, the ribs the cavern of *qi*. They unite the spirit of the head above with the power of the feet, waist, and hips below, forming the great nexus of the entire body. Like the door of a house or the pass of a nation, if the door does not open, there is no passage for coming or going. Thus, the shoulders’ function has eight essentials: *tong* (through), *tou* (penetrate), *chuan* (pierce), *tie* (adhere), *song* (relax), *han* (sweat), *he* (unite), and *jian* (firm). The ribs’ function has two: opening and expanding, tightening and gathering. Mastering these secrets, one grasps more than half the wonders of the middle region.

What is the ultimate destination of *jin*? It lies in the feet. The feet are the root of all limbs, bearing the entire body—like all things growing from soil and standing upon the earth, where decline and vigor, form and posture, all depend on the ground. If the earth is not vast and thick, how can it bear all things? Thus, the feet are the source of *jin*’s issuance. Every release and relaxation arises from the *yongquan* (Bubbling Spring) point beneath the feet; every contraction and tension returns to the *yongquan* to subside. This is the essential secret of the lower path and the foundation of all skill.

Understanding these three—head, shoulders and ribs, feet—one may grasp the general outline. Yet what remains to be emphasized above all?
